simpledb

Class IntHistogram

  • java.lang.Object
    • simpledb.IntHistogram

  • public class IntHistogram
extends java.lang.Object
    A class to represent a fixed-width histogram over a single integer-based field.

    • Constructor Summary

    • Constructor Detail

      • IntHistogram

        public IntHistogram(int buckets,
            int min,
            int max)
        Create a new IntHistogram. This IntHistogram should maintain a histogram of integer values that it receives. It should split the histogram into "buckets" buckets. The values that are being histogrammed will be provided one-at-a-time through the "addValue()" function. Your implementation should use space and have execution time that are both constant with respect to the number of values being histogrammed. For example, you shouldn't simply store every value that you see in a sorted list.
        Parameters:
        buckets - The number of buckets to split the input value into.
        min - The minimum integer value that will ever be passed to this class for histogramming
        max - The maximum integer value that will ever be passed to this class for histogramming

    • Method Detail

      • addValue

        public void addValue(int v)
        Add a value to the set of values that you are keeping a histogram of.
        Parameters:
        v - Value to add to the histogram

      • estimateSelectivity

        public double estimateSelectivity(Predicate.Op op,
                         int v)
        Estimate the selectivity of a particular predicate and operand on this table. For example, if "op" is "GREATER_THAN" and "v" is 5, return your estimate of the fraction of elements that are greater than 5.
        Parameters:
        op - Operator
        v - Value
        Returns:
        Predicted selectivity of this particular operator and value

      • avgSelectivity

        public double avgSelectivity()
        Returns:
        the average selectivity of this histogram. This is not an indispensable method to implement the basic join optimization. It may be needed if you want to implement a more efficient optimization

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()
        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object
        Returns:
        A string describing this histogram, for debugging purposes
